a8c72e29-86e6-41c0-96d6-dc2519dac431.content:
Symptoms include:

  • Unable to speak or cough
  • Face turning red or blue
  • Distressed and clutching or pointing to throat

9a5ade48-99ee-41f1-a782-1bcd1c44cb28.content:
What Should You Do?


1. Cough it out

  • Ask them 'Are you choking?'
  • Tell them to 'Cough it out'

2. Slap it out

  • Lean them forwards (they can put their hands on their knees)
  • Give up to 5 back blows between the shoulder blades with the flat of your hand
  • Check their mouth for the food and remove

3. Squeeze it out

  • Give up to 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich Manouvre)
  • Stand behind them, put your arms around them
  • Put a fist between their tummy button and chest, just under the ribcage
  • Grasp your fist with the other hand
  • Pull sharply inwards and upwards
  • Check their mouth for the food and remove

4. Call an ambulance

  • Keep repeating the 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts
  • If the casualty becomes unresponsive, begin chest compressions

4e312214-a007-4dee-9052-381b3c2592ba.content:
Even if you do not manage to remove the lodged food, do not give up hope. There have been cases of people being kept alive by chest compressions even after they have lost consiousness, then being saved by the paramedics.


If the person becomes unresponsive, keep going with chest compressions until someone else can take over or you become too exhausted to continue.
4e312214-a007-4dee-9052-381b3c2592ba.title: Chest Compressions Can Save Lives
